div.p: RB MSS M100a, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.

Let me thank you, dear Louise, for the beautiful photogram, which you sent me, and which shall have a most honored place in the Album of those photographic cards, which I value most.
See M to L. Wehl, 25 December 1884, in which M requests a photograph of her.Noimageof Wehlhas been identified at MEL, but see M to J. Haast, 29 July 1862 (in this edition as 62-07-29b) and notes thereto.
Though different to your expression some years ago, it is not a less delightful one. I was glad, to percieve, that the volume of Lytton's poems pleased you.
Not identified.
As a scholar in ancient as well as modern languages, he has a great command over words, and he imbibed much of his expressions from Schiller. I had the honor of interchanging letters with him 25 years ago.
See M to E. Bulwer Lytton, 16 August 1858.
If you have never read his translations of Schiller's poems, I can send you my copy on loan.
M first became aware of the translation in the edition ofSchiller (1844)(see M to E Bulwer Lytton, 24 November 1864, in this edition as 64-11-24e). It is not however known whether the edition he later owned is that editionor Schiller (1852).
Unfortunately I could not get an other here nor readily in Europe. It is my intention to sit once more for a photographic picture, probably in 1885; somehow never a good likeness of me was taken anywhere. When it is done, I shall have the happiness of sending dear niece Louise a copy.
